name: Octavia Butler’s Science Fiction Predicted the World We Live In

content.html: “What readers, fans and scholars often note about Butler’s work is its predictive qualities: Her vision about the climate crisis, political and societal upheaval and the brutality and consequences of power hierarchies seems both sobering and prescient.” She was brilliant. And this tribute is beautifully done. #Culture
content.value: “What readers, fans and scholars often note about Butler’s work is its predictive qualities: Her vision about the climate crisis, political and societal upheaval and the brutality and consequences of power hierarchies seems both sobering and prescient.” She was brilliant. And this tribute is beautifully done. #Culture

content.html: “The speed with which Twitter recedes in your mind will shock you. Like a demon from a folktale, the kind that only gains power when you invite it into your home, the platform melts like mist when that invitation is rescinded.” #Twitter
content.value: “The speed with which Twitter recedes in your mind will shock you. Like a demon from a folktale, the kind that only gains power when you invite it into your home, the platform melts like mist when that invitation is rescinded.” #Twitter

content.html: “In 2016, BuzzFeed stories posted on the platform had 329 million engagements; by 2018, that number had fallen to less than half. Last year, BuzzFeed posts received 29 million engagements, and this year is shaping up to be even worse.” I had no idea it had fallen so far. #Media
content.value: “In 2016, BuzzFeed stories posted on the platform had 329 million engagements; by 2018, that number had fallen to less than half. Last year, BuzzFeed posts received 29 million engagements, and this year is shaping up to be even worse.” I had no idea it had fallen so far. #Media

name: Twitter as representation of the relevance and value of “Word People” in oral culture

content.html: “It’s interesting to divide the internet into Word People and Image People because the Internet is a modern evolution of oral culture — and technological/bandwidth limitations have enabled text to serve as the leading means to transfer information online up till now.” #Twitter
content.value: “It’s interesting to divide the internet into Word People and Image People because the Internet is a modern evolution of oral culture — and technological/bandwidth limitations have enabled text to serve as the leading means to transfer information online up till now.” #Twitter

name: Most media predicted a red wave. Here’s how The 19th got the election right.

content.html: “The media missed the concerns and the motivations of many voters and failed to capture the full electorate. At The 19th, we remained focused on you.” I’m proud, as always, to work here. #Media
content.value: “The media missed the concerns and the motivations of many voters and failed to capture the full electorate. At The 19th, we remained focused on you.” I’m proud, as always, to work here. #Media

name: What’s Twitter’s Future? The Former Head of Trust And Safety Weighs In

content.html: “It was for this reason that I chose to leave the company: A Twitter whose policies are defined by edict has little need for a trust and safety function dedicated to its principled development.” #Twitter
content.value: “It was for this reason that I chose to leave the company: A Twitter whose policies are defined by edict has little need for a trust and safety function dedicated to its principled development.” #Twitter

name: Twitter had 7500 staff to begin with. Then Musk fired a lot, dropping the total to 3700. Now 1200 have opted to take severance, leaving the total at 2500. Do I have that right? I wonder what that looks like across teams?

content.html: Twitter had 7500 staff to begin with. Then Musk fired a lot, dropping the total to 3700. Now 1200 have opted to take severance, leaving the total at 2500. Do I have that right? I wonder what that looks like across teams?

name: ‘People underestimated them’: Advocates for Black women in politics want the Democratic Party to learn from the midterms

content.html: “We need early investments for these Black women candidates – Black candidates in general – but especially for Black women, who we know receive less financial contributions than a White woman or a White man running for these positions.” #Democracy
content.value: “We need early investments for these Black women candidates – Black candidates in general – but especially for Black women, who we know receive less financial contributions than a White woman or a White man running for these positions.” #Democracy

name:
People are saying things like “let’s get back on AIM” and I’m just sitting in the corner pre-dating everything everyone comes up with and feeling as old as literal dust.

“Remember MySpace?” Why, yes I do. I was saving into a pension at the time.

name: Tech Titans Like Elon Musk Want to Save Earth by Having Tons of Children

content.html: “We are the Underground Railroad of 'Gattaca' babies and people who want to do genetic stuff with their kids.” Go ahead and tell me this isn’t white supremacy. #Society
content.value: “We are the Underground Railroad of 'Gattaca' babies and people who want to do genetic stuff with their kids.” Go ahead and tell me this isn’t white supremacy. #Society

name: The people pulling through for Musk and sleeping on office floors are selling out their colleagues - and particularly the ones who can’t do that because of their life circumstances. It’s not remotely admirable and I hope their names are remembered.

content.html: The people pulling through for Musk and sleeping on office floors are selling out their colleagues - and particularly the ones who can’t do that because of their life circumstances. It’s not remotely admirable and I hope their names are remembered.

name: John Fetterman and Social Media: How His Campaign Built a Winning Strategy

content.html: “The entire time I was running this program, I was like, “This is going to be a presidential-[campaign] level team in the content we produce and money we raise and folks who organize.” I do think it will be an example for other campaigns. I hope what we do sets an example for the upcoming presidential cycle.” #Democracy
content.value: “The entire time I was running this program, I was like, “This is going to be a presidential-[campaign] level team in the content we produce and money we raise and folks who organize.” I do think it will be an example for other campaigns. I hope what we do sets an example for the upcoming presidential cycle.” #Democracy

name: I don’t think this is going to be a good few years for tech. (The signs are subtle, I’m sure you’ll agree.) If you’re in the industry, plan accordingly. If you’re not but heavily depend on specific SaaS platforms, make contingency plans.

content.html: I don’t think this is going to be a good few years for tech. (The signs are subtle, I’m sure you’ll agree.) If you’re in the industry, plan accordingly. If you’re not but heavily depend on specific SaaS platforms, make contingency plans.
content.value: I don’t think this is going to be a good few years for tech. (The signs are subtle, I’m sure you’ll agree.) If you’re in the industry, plan accordingly. If you’re not but heavily depend on specific SaaS platforms, make contingency plans.

name: Interview: Fallen crypto CEO Sam Bankman-Fried opens up about FTX, Alameda Research, and his regrets

content.html: “It was past midnight Bahamas time, where Bankman-Fried is reportedly still located, and we went back and forth on Twitter for more than an hour.” Remarkable interview. #Crypto
content.value: “It was past midnight Bahamas time, where Bankman-Fried is reportedly still located, and we went back and forth on Twitter for more than an hour.” Remarkable interview. #Crypto

name: Why Meta’s withdrawal from journalism will hurt local media companies

content.html: “Looking beyond LMA, any guesses on who is the largest funder of Report for America? That’s right. The Meta Journalism Project donated $6.5 million. I believe that’s a little more than 40% of the total raised to date. That means 120 reporters could go away if other funders don’t step up.” Repeat after me: don’t depend on Meta. For anything. #Media

content.html: This makes me so sad. I really loved Protocol. #Media

name: If You Want to Understand How Dangerous Elon Musk Is, Look Outside America

content.html: “Musk is right that the world needs a digital public square; unfortunately, he seems to have little idea that creating one involves balancing free speech against abuse, misinformation and government overreach.” #Media
content.value: “Musk is right that the world needs a digital public square; unfortunately, he seems to have little idea that creating one involves balancing free speech against abuse, misinformation and government overreach.” #Media

name: Is Elon Musk a bad boss? Ask Tesla, SpaceX, Twitter workers

content.html: “But there’s plenty in the public record. Personal attacks. Union busting. A casual attitude toward factory floor injuries and other health concerns. A dismissive approach to workplace racism. And an allegation involving a horse and sexual favors.” #Business
content.value: “But there’s plenty in the public record. Personal attacks. Union busting. A casual attitude toward factory floor injuries and other health concerns. A dismissive approach to workplace racism. And an allegation involving a horse and sexual favors.” #Business

name: Join us at our free Future of the Workforce event in Austin tomorrow

content.html:
I’m in Austin for The 19th’s Future of the Workforce event at the South Congress Hotel tomorrow. It’s free to attend in person, and I’d love to see you there! And if you’re further afield, you can still register to watch online.

From the event page:

Are the shifting norms of the last few years here to stay — or will large businesses continue to push for a return to pre-pandemic “normal?” How can business leaders balance economic growth and emerging technologies with the rights and needs of workers? The 19th is gathering business and policy leaders who think deeply about labor to discuss the future of the workforce.

It’s going to be a great event. Please join us.
content.value: I’m in Austin for The 19th’s Future of the Workforce event at the South Congress Hotel tomorrow. It’s free to attend in person, and I’d love to see you there! And if you’re further afield, you can still register to watch online.From the event page:Are the shifting norms of the last few years here to stay — or will large businesses continue to push for a return to pre-pandemic “normal?” How can business leaders balance economic growth and emerging technologies with the rights and needs of workers? The 19th is gathering business and policy leaders who think deeply about labor to discuss the future of the workforce. It’s going to be a great event. Please join us.

name: Media Companies Are Having Their Worst Year in Three Decades

content.html: “Advertising and affiliate fees are the two biggest revenue streams for most traditional media companies. Now they are both in secular decline.” #Media
content.value: “Advertising and affiliate fees are the two biggest revenue streams for most traditional media companies. Now they are both in secular decline.” #Media

name: Facing a call for climate reparations, wealthy nations propose an insurance scheme

content.html: “Advocates for loss and damage warned that insurance schemes like those promised by Global Shield are an insufficient solution to loss and damage, and they worried that such programs will distract from the demand for separate direct funding.” #Climate
content.value: “Advocates for loss and damage warned that insurance schemes like those promised by Global Shield are an insufficient solution to loss and damage, and they worried that such programs will distract from the demand for separate direct funding.” #Climate
